title: Exploring Data: Five-Number Summary and Outliers
driving_question: How can we use the five-number summary and outlier detection methods to analyze a dataset?
short_background_context: In this mission, we will explore the concepts of five-number summary and outlier detection in the context of a real-world scenario: analyzing the length of hospital stays. The five-number summary includes the minimum, lower quartile (Q1), median, upper quartile (Q3), and maximum of a dataset. Outliers are values that are significantly different from other observations in the dataset. There are different methods to identify outliers, and we will focus on two: Method A, which considers a value an outlier if it is greater than 1.5 times the interquartile range (IQR) above Q3 or below Q1, and Method B, which considers a value an outlier if it is 2 or more standard deviations away from the mean.
tasks: Calculate the five-number summary of a given dataset representing the length of hospital stays.
Identify outliers in the dataset using Method A and justify your findings.
Identify outliers in the dataset using Method B and justify your findings.
pre_thinking_prompts: What does the five-number summary tell us about a dataset?
Why is it important to identify outliers in a dataset?
How might the two methods of identifying outliers yield different results?
reflection_prompt: Reflect on how understanding the five-number summary and outliers can help in analyzing real-world datasets. How did the two methods of identifying outliers compare?
ai_tutor_prompts: What does the median tell us about the dataset?
Can you explain why you identified those values as outliers using Method A?
Why did you choose those values as outliers using Method B? How does this method differ from Method A?
remix_zone: Students could remix this problem by using a different dataset, such as test scores or heights of individuals, and applying the same concepts of five-number summary and outlier detection.
